column1: In Manhattan Community Access Corp. v. Halleck, will the Supreme Court rule that the Manhattan Neighborhood Network is a public forum for First Amendment purposes?
column6: ['Society']
column11: A suit over First Amendment rights violations was dismissed by the district court, concluding that First Amendment protections do not apply to Manhattan Neighborhood Network because it is not a public forum and its employees are not state actors (Reuters, Oyez, SCOTUSBlog). The appeals court reversed in part, ruling that public access TV channels in Manhattan are public forums and the case should proceed (SCOTUSBlog). The Supreme Court is expected to hand down its decision in its current term, but if it does not, the question will resolve as no. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: The contract for monopoly rights includes the provision to provide public access channels. A private entity having accepted the duties of government cannot obtain an end-run novation that allows the benefits without the obligations. Would expect the court to write an opinion noting that private actors might easily avoid the result with careful negotiations, indemnity, etc.

A private company awarded a franchise does not become a public forum. I believe this is a 9-0 decision for MNN. If public access channel is meant to be a public forum then some form of agreement between State and Company is needed to affirm.
I believe SCOTUS will rule that Manhattan Neighborhood Network is covered by the 1st Ammendment right to free speech.

I suspect that SCOTUS would hand down an affirmative verdict, however, SCOTUS has enough on it's plate that it is also likely that they won't get to this question. Hence, likely yes with likely no judgement is a 50-50 shot.
I think given this is not clear cut, if they rule yes this will set a precedent and potentially open up many other similar grey area situations to first amendment impact

Let's run down the Justices:

I would expect a narrow ruling on this; the organization of the channel provided below makes a good case for it being handed down to a lower court, and I don't think this case is likely to open the proverbial floodgates on other public forum cases.
Returning the case to the lower court with instructions best outcome and good judgment ü¶â‚ôªÔ∏è

SCOTUS is loath to uphold First Amendment restrictions. The Court is perfectly capable of writing a narrowly circumscribed decision. There is a likelihood also that at least one conservative Justice writing a concurring opinion citing Alito's unregulated Internet concerns. But given that the lower court violated SCOTUS by considering whether the MNN is a "public forum" before considering whether the platform is a "State Actor" there is a chance SCOTUS will return the matter to the lower Court.

I'd be almost certain here, but there's a chance the Court will find that MNN is not a public forum; the conservative justices cannot be counted on to rule as a block, even on First Amendment issues, and we don't know enough about how the two newish Justices see private property cases now that they're beyond recall.

As an initial matter--the question is somewhat poorly worded, because the Manhattan Neighborhood Network is simply a dba of the Manhattan Community Access Corporation and the moniker "MNN" may actually just be intellectual property of the non-profit corporation. I take the question to mean whether the public access channels it administers will be deemed to be public forums. Indeed, the respondents note that if the City transferred the public access channels to another entity to administer, the new administrator may not be able to use the name ‚ÄúManhattan Neighborhood Network‚Äù or other intellectual property that MNN might claim to own. But the public forum is not the channels‚Äô name. It is the public access channels themselves‚Äîwhich the City controls." This is also the crux of the respondents' argument.
